title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement phgrosjean@sciviews.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Rich-formatted Tables with Tabularise
text: Let’s use ToothGrowth {datasets} example. can directly add labels units, use data.io::labellise() (optional step): usual output data frame R (, short version first 6 lines) quite basic terms formatting: outputs acceptable R script, may notebook, polished document (report, presentation, paper, book…) Several packages provide functions better format outputs reporting publications, {flextable}, {gt} {tinytable} among others. {tabularise} uses enhances {flextable} nicely format various tables allow output HTML, LaTeX/PDF, Word PowerPoint. tabularise() function automatically uses labels units variables present data frame (note tabularise$<type>(....) variant tabularise(...., type = headtail)). Tooth growth  [mm] Supplement Vitamin C  [mg/d] 4.2 VC 0.5 11.5 VC 0.5 7.3 VC 0.5 5.8 VC 0.5 6.4 VC 0.5 ... ... ... 30.9 OJ 2.0 26.4 OJ 2.0 27.3 OJ 2.0 29.4 OJ 2.0 23.0 OJ 2.0 First last 5 rows total 60 course, output tabularise() flextable object, can customize using functions provided {flextable}. Effect Vitamin C Tooth Growth Guinea Pigs Tooth growth  [mm] Supplement Vitamin C  [mg/d] 4.2 VC 0.5 11.5 VC 0.5 7.3 VC 0.5 5.8 VC 0.5 6.4 VC 0.5 ... ... ... 30.9 OJ 2.0 26.4 OJ 2.0 27.3 OJ 2.0 29.4 OJ 2.0 23.0 OJ 2.0 First last 5 rows total 60 couple tables provided {tabularise} data.frame, matrix, Correlation objects. However, coverage intentionally low. Many tables provided packages depend import {tabularise}, like: inferit formats tables produced htest objects {stats} package modelit includes set practical functions formatting tables various models lm, glm, nls, anova; aov objects {stats} package. exploreit (coming soon…) come… explore packages see can . examples use, can browse biological data science course inline (French).
code: data("ToothGrowth", package = "datasets") # Add labels and units ToothGrowth <- data.io::labelise(ToothGrowth,   label = list(len = "Tooth growth", supp = "Supplement", dose = "Vitamin C"),   units = list(len = "mm", dose = "mg/d")) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'data.io': #>   method             from   #>   $.subsettable_type svMisc head(ToothGrowth) #>    len supp dose #> 1  4.2   VC  0.5 #> 2 11.5   VC  0.5 #> 3  7.3   VC  0.5 #> 4  5.8   VC  0.5 #> 5  6.4   VC  0.5 #> 6 10.0   VC  0.5 library(tabularise) tabularise$headtail(ToothGrowth)  #> Warning in set2(resolve(...)): The object is read-only and cannot be modified. #> If you have to modify it for a legitimate reason, call the method $lock(FALSE) #> on the object before $set(). Using $lock(FALSE) to modify the object will be #> enforced in future versions of knitr and this warning will become an error. tabularise$headtail(ToothGrowth) |>   flextable::add_header_lines(     values = "Effect of Vitamin C on Tooth Growth in Guinea Pigs") #> Warning in set2(resolve(...)): The object is read-only and cannot be modified. #> If you have to modify it for a legitimate reason, call the method $lock(FALSE) #> on the object before $set(). Using $lock(FALSE) to modify the object will be #> enforced in future versions of knitr and this warning will become an error.

title: Rich-formatted Tables with Tabularise
text: several tables (like models {modelit} package), LaTeX equations created displayed table. {tabularise} provides equation() generic function create LaTeX code. One can also provide directly LaTeX instruction equation(): \[ y = \alpha + \beta_1 \cdot x + \beta_2 \cdot x^2 \] course, function useful ,n equation constructed model (using {equatiomatic} package). \[ \begin{aligned} \operatorname{Tooth\ growth \ [mm]} &= \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{Vitamin\ C \ [mg/d]}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{Supplement}_{\operatorname{VC}})\ + \\ &\quad \beta_{3}(\operatorname{Vitamin\ C \ [mg/d]} \times \operatorname{Supplement}_{\operatorname{VC}}) + \epsilon \end{aligned} \] Note equation() also automatically uses labels units, can turned argument auto.labs = FALSE. See ?tabularise::equation ?equatiomatic::extract_eq various arguments. {tabularise} also provides eq_() eq__() functions ease inclusion equations R Markdown Quarto documents. eq_() function, used R console RStudio outputs formatted version equation Viewer pane. useful preview final version equation R. also useful produce equations inline R chunks like \(\operatorname{len} = \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{dose}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{supp}_{\operatorname{VC}}) + \beta_{3}(\operatorname{dose} \times \operatorname{supp}_{\operatorname{VC}}) + \epsilon\). eq__() function used R Markdown Quarto documents produce LaTeX code equation integrated equation display markdown tag like : \[\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Tooth\ growth \ [mm]} &= \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{Vitamin\ C \ [mg/d]}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{Supplement}_{\operatorname{VC}})\ + \\ &\quad \beta_{3}(\operatorname{Vitamin\ C \ [mg/d]} \times \operatorname{Supplement}_{\operatorname{VC}}) + \epsilon \end{aligned}\] functions can used independently tabularise() manage model equations various documents.
code: eq <- equation("y = \\alpha + \\beta_1 \\cdot x + \\beta_2 \\cdot x^2") eq tg_lm <- lm(len ~ dose * supp, data = ToothGrowth) tg_eq <- equation(tg_lm, terms_per_line = 3, wrap = TRUE) tg_eq

title: Create Tabular Outputs from R
text: {tabularise} available CRAN yet. install SciViews R-Universe. {equatags} {equatiomatic} packages optional, useful display equations, inline R Markdown/Quarto documents {tabularise} tables. {data.io} package useful manages labels units {chart} uses. install three packages dependencies, run following command R: can also install latest development version {tabularise}. Make sure {remotes} R package installed:
code: install.packages(c('tabularise', 'equatags', 'equatiomatic', 'data.io'),   repos = c('https://sciviews.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("SciViews/tabularise")

title: Create Tabular Outputs from R
text: Let’s take well-known iris data frame, add labels units. labels units added data frame, tabularise() function uses automatically tables produces.  {tabularise} central package used several packages SciViews universe format tabular outputs. Various methods available tabularise() enhanced packages, {inferit} {modelit}.
code: data("iris")  # Add labels and units iris <- data.io::labelise(iris,   label = list(     Sepal.Length = "Sepal length", Sepal.Width = "Sepal width",     Petal.Length  = "Petal length", Petal.Width = "Petal width",      Species  = "Iris species"),   units = list(     Sepal.Length = "cm", Sepal.Width = "cm",     Petal.Length  = "cm", Petal.Width = "cm")) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'data.io': #>   method             from   #>   $.subsettable_type svMisc library(tabularise) tabularise$headtail(iris) # or tabularise(iris, type = "headtail")

title: Scientific format for columns in {flextable} — colformat_sci
text: x flextable object rows selection j columns selection digits number digits display scipen penalty use decide numbers presented decimal scientific notation (generally use 0 -1) lod value indicating limit detection, display something like '< lod_value' instead actual value; useful p values (R often uses 2e-16 case), chemical measurements ... lod_str string use, default, < lod_value. fancy use perfect scientific notation (TRUE) simplified one like 1.34e-5 (FALSE). op operator character use fancy scientific notation

what: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
text: Extract create LaTeX equation describe model, directly LaTeX code. objects supported equatiomatic::extract_eq() supported default method description.

title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
code: equation(object, ...)  # S3 method for default equation(   object,   auto.labs = TRUE,   origdata = NULL,   labs = NULL,   swap_var_names = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for character equation(object, ...)  eq__(object, ...)  eq_(object, ...)  # S3 method for inline_equation print(x, ...)

title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
text: object object model whose equation constructed. character object provided, concatenated single character string equation class, otherwise non transformed (supposed valid LaTeX equation). Remember backslashes must doubled regular R strings, use r"(...)" notation, may comfortable , see examples. ... parameters passed equatiomatic::extract_eq() (see man page). auto.labs TRUE (default), use labels (units) automatically data origdata=. origdata original data set model fitted . default NULL label used. labs Labels change names elements term column table. default NULL term changed. swap_var_names Change variable names values, regardless values auto.labs= labs= ignored argument used. Provide named character string name variables strings new names. can use ^ _ indicate next character, next integer super) subscript equation. x inline_equation object generated eq_().`

title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
text: object class c("equation", "character").

title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
text: slight differences equation(), eq_() eq__(): equation() returns string LaTeX code prints LaTeX code R console. eq_() returns LaTeX code surrounded dollar sign $...$ suitable build inline equations R Markdown/Quarto documents using inline R code. prints rendered inline equation RStudio Viewer browser. advised rapidly preview resulting equation. eq__() returns LaTeX code surrounded dollar signs simple character string. just prompts LaTeX string R console. used R inline chunk inside $$...$$ construct Markdown text. result display equation can also cross referenced Quarto usual way label , e.g., use $$...$$ {#eq-label}.

title: Get a LaTeX equation from a model or from LaTeX code — equation
code: iris_lm <- lm(data = iris, Petal.Length ~ Sepal.Length + Species) summary(iris_lm) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = Petal.Length ~ Sepal.Length + Species, data = iris) #>  #> Residuals: #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -0.76390 -0.17875  0.00716  0.17461  0.79954  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)       -1.70234    0.23013  -7.397 1.01e-11 *** #> Sepal.Length       0.63211    0.04527  13.962  < 2e-16 *** #> Speciesversicolor  2.21014    0.07047  31.362  < 2e-16 *** #> Speciesvirginica   3.09000    0.09123  33.870  < 2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.2826 on 146 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.9749,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.9744  #> F-statistic:  1890 on 3 and 146 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 #>  equation(iris_lm) #> $$ #> \operatorname{Petal.Length} = \alpha + \beta_{1}(\operatorname{Sepal.Length}) + \beta_{2}(\operatorname{Species}_{\operatorname{versicolor}}) + \beta_{3}(\operatorname{Species}_{\operatorname{virginica}}) + \epsilon #> $$ # Providing directly the LaTeX code of the equation (variance of a sample) equation("S^2_y = \\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \\frac{(y_i - \\bar{Y})^2}{n}") #> $$ #> S^2_y = \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{(y_i - \bar{Y})^2}{n} #> $$ # Easier to write like this (avoiding the double backslashes): eq1 <- equation(r"(S^2_y = \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{(y_i - \bar{Y})^2}{n})") # Print raw text: eq1 #> $$ #> S^2_y = \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{(y_i - \bar{Y})^2}{n} #> $$ # Get a preview of the equation eq__(eq1) #> [1] "S^2_y = \\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \\frac{(y_i - \\bar{Y})^2}{n}" # The same function can be used inside a `$$...$$ {#eq-label}` construct in # R Markdown or Quarto to calcule a display equation that is also recognized # by the cross referencing system of Quarto. # Get a string suitable for inclusion inline in R Markdown with `r eq_(eq1)` # (inside Markdown text and without the dollar signs around it) eq_(eq1)

title: Create Tabular Outputs from R — tabularise-package
text: Create rich-formatted tabular outputs various R objects can incorporated R Markdown/Quarto documents correct output least HTML, LaTeX/PDF, Word PowerPoint various R objects.

title: Create Tabular Outputs from R — tabularise-package
text: object class, "default" method creates obvious tabular form object, might also types provided different tabular views object. types accessible tabularise() function accepts type= argument, better, using compact easier read tabularise$type() form.

title: Create Tabular Outputs from R — tabularise-package
text: tabularise() constructs table (flextable object default, tinytable object kind = "tt"). Stb collection functions manipulate format table (mostly functions {flextable} package. colformat_sci() colformat_md() additional columns formatters flextable objects, respectively, scientific markdown formats. para_md() creates {flextable} paragraphs rich-formatting converting Markdown strings {flextable} paragraphs.
